Abstract 1 In the present study, a new and efficient nanosorbent for the fast removal of heavy 2 metal ions was prepared. The proposed nanosorbent was fabricated using Fe3O4 magnetic 3 core shelled by mesoporous silica, and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as 4 surfactant template through a sol-gel process. The magnetic nanomaterial was further 5 modified with bis(3-triethoxysilylpropyl)tetrasulfide (MSCMNPs-S4). The final nanosphers 6 were characterized by FT-IR, XRD, TGA, BET, SEM, TEM, DLS, VSM, EDX, and UV-Vis. 7 The potential of the resultant mesoporous magnetite nanomaterials was investigated as a 8 convenient and effective adsorbent for the removal of toxic heavy metal ions from aqueous 9 solutions in a batch system. The effect of essential parameters on the removal efficiency 10 including initial pH of sample solution, adsorbent amount, metal ion concentration, contact 11 time and type and quantity of the eluent on the adsorption characteristics of the MSCMNPs-12 S4 were studied. Under the optimized conditions, the proposed nanosorbent exhibited high 13 adsorption capacity of 303.03, 256.41 and 270.27 mg g-1 and maximum removal percentages 14 of 98.8%, 96.4%, 95.7% for Hg(II), Pd(II) and Pb(II) ions, respectively. The mechanism of 15 the adsorbtion was found to be in good agreement with the Langmuir isotherm model. 16 Furthermore, the reusability investigation indicated that the MSCMNPs-S4 could be used 17 frequently at least for five cycles without any significant loss in its performance. 18 19 Keywords: Magnetite-mesoporous silica, Adsorbent, Heavy metal, Atomic absorption 20 spectroscopy 21 22

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 23
sections.text:
Progress in industrial life of human causes water pollution by heavy metal become one 24 of the hot topics in environmental researches and attracted global attention. Heavy metals can 25
seriously affect the human and environment health [1]. For this purpose, the development of 1 reliable methods for the determination and removal of these species in drinkable and 2 environmental water sources is of great importance [2]. Until now, various treatment 3 techniques have been applied for the efficient removal of harmful metal ions from solutions, 4 such as ion exchange [3], membrane filtration [4], chemical precipitation [5], coagulation 5 flocculation [6], adsorption [7], reverse osmosis [8] and electrochemical technologies [9]. 6 Adsorption using suitable adsorbent is one of the above-mentioned methods, which is most 7 efficient, effective, fast, simple and economical method for the remove of metal ions from 8 water and wastewater sources [10, 11]. 9 Recently, by rapid development of nanotechnology, magnetic nanoparticles have 10 employed widely as adsorbent for the effective removal of pollutants from aqueous solutions 11 [12-15]. Among all the reported magnetic nanoparticles, Fe3O4 nanoparticles have attracted 12 great inclination due to their strong magnetic property, chemical stability, high specific 13 surface area, , high dispersibility, low toxicity, uniform sizes, regular shapes, excellent 14 biocompatibility and easily surface modification [16, 17]. Besides these constructive features, 15 magnetic nanoparticles are associated with several flaws such as instability under acidic 16 conditions, aggregation and oxidation in air [18]. To overcome these deficiencies, 17 modification of the magnetic nanoparticles surface with a suitable coating compound such as 18 silica can greatly enhances the stability of the nanoparticles and prevents their aggregation 19 [19, 20]. Magnetic mesoporous silica nanosphere, containing an magnetic iron oxide core 20 nanoparticles and a silica shell, have found particular applications in various research fields 21 including catalysis [21], adsorption [22], drug delivery [23], sensor [24], biomedicine [25], 22 imprinting [26], separation [27] and water treatment [28]. In recent decade, organic 23 functionalized mesoporous silica materials have generated considerable interest as suitable 24 adsorbents for adsorptive removal of aqueous pollutants because of their unique 25
physicochemical properties [29-32]. Therefore, many attempts have been devoted to 1 preparation, applications, and characterizations, of magnetic mesoporous silica nanospheres 2 with controlled particle size, pore diameter, and morphologies [22, 33-40]. For example, the 3 mesoporous magnetic nanomaterials which functionalized with amine have been used to 4 removal of Cd(II), Pb(II), and Cu(II) from aqueous samples [41, 42]. 5 The aim of the present study, considering above mentioned, is synthesize a new 6 adsorbent based on magnetic mesoporous silica nanomaterial functionalized with bis(3-7 triethoxysilylpropyl)tetrasulfide for the adsorption of toxic metal ions from aqueous solutions 8 in a batch procedure. For this purpose, firstly, the Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles were 9 prepared through precipitation method, and then, mesoporous silica shell were successfully 10 coated on the magnetic core in a sol-gel process using a silica source of tetraethyl 11 orthosilicate (TEOS), and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as surfactant template. 12 The effect of different parameters including adsorbent dosage, initial pH, initial metal ion 13 concentration, contact time, and type and quantity of eluent on removing Hg(II), Pd(II) and 14 Pb(II) ions from aqueous solutions was investigated. 15 16

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Synthesis of Fe3O4 nanoparticles (MNPs) 9
sections.text:
Fe3O4 nanoparticles were synthesized through a chemical precipitation method 10 according to previous reported work [43]. Briefly, FeCl2·4H2O (4.30 g) and FeCl3·6H2O 11 (11.68 g) were successfully dissolved under a N2 atmosphere in 200 mL of deionized water 12 with fast mixing at 85 °C. Afterwards, 25 mL of an aqueous solution of NH4OH (25%) was 13 slowly added to the container, and then the solution color changed rapidly to black (from 14 orange color of iron salts solution). The resulted Fe3O4 nanoparticles were collected, washed 15 thrice with deionized water and once with 100 mL sodium chloride (0.02 mol L-1), and 16 dispersed in deionized water for further use. 17 18 2.3.2. The silica coated Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles were prepared similar to our previous 22 work [43] with a minor modification. To prepare SiO2-coated magnetic nanoparticles, the 23 prepared magnetite suspension (25 mL) placed in a vessel, and allowed to settle by external 24 magnet. After removing the supernatant, 80 mL of aqueous solution of TEOS (, 10% v/v) was 25
added, followed by 60 mL glycerol and the pH of the mixture was lowered using glacial 1 acetic acid to 4.6. Then, the suspension heated and stirred mechanically for 2 hours under the 2 nitrogen atmosphere at 90 °C. After finishing the reaction, the product was cooled at room 3 temperature and obtained materials were separated by applying a external magnetic field. 4 Finally, the silica-coated magnetic nanoparticles, washed with deionized water (500 mL) and 5 ethanol (500 mL) several time, and dispersed in deionized water for further use. 6 7 2.3.3. sections.text: Due to test the stability and reusability of the mesoporous adsorbent, the adsorption-13 desorption experiments of the prepared MSCMNPs-S4 nanospheres were performed in five 14 repeated cycles. In each cycle, 50 mg adsorbent was put in 25 mL conical flasks containing 15 10 mL of 20 mg L-1 Hg(II), Pd(II) and Pb(II) ions individually standard solution and the 16 mixture was shaken at 350 rpm for 1 hour at ambient temperature. The mesoporous 17 nanospheres were magnetically separated and the supernatant was measured to heavy metals 18 measurements. The adsorbed metal ions were washed with 10 mL 1 M HNO3 and the 19 concentrations of desorbed metal ions were detected with AAS. The FT-IR spectra of MNPs, SCMNPs, MSCMNPs, and MSCMNPs-S4 are shown in 3 Fig. 1. For the pure Fe3O4, the strong absorption bands at around 573 and 457 cm -1 4 correspond to the stretching vibration of the Fe-O bonds. After coating the magnetite 5 nanoparticles with a mesoporous silica layer, new absorption peaks at 1095 and 805 cm-1 are 6 attributed to the stretching vibrations (asymmetric) of Si-O-Si and stretching vibration of Si-7 O-H, respectively. All these bands in Fig. 1 indicate that SiO2 has been successfully coated 8 on the surface of Fe3O4. For CTAB@MSCMNPs, two absorption peaks at 2850 to 2990 cm -1 9 are attributed to asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of -CH2 from of CTAB 10 template, respectively. In addition, the absorption broad bands at 3475 cm-1 correspond to the 11 hydroxyl bond. After surfactant extraction, no characteristic peak was observed in the 2800 - 12 3000 cm-1 range for MSCMNPs that indicates the effective remove of CTAB templates. sections.heading: 3.2. Adsorption studies of the mesoporous MSCMNPs-S4 magnetic adsorbent for the 16

removal of heavy metal ions from water 17 Different mechanisms have been proposed for affinity-based interactions of heavy metals 18 with sulfur functionalities. Sulfur increases the surface polarity and enhances negative charge 19 on the surface to attract the positively charged heavy metal cation. According to Pearson 20 theory, the affinity of heavy metals towards sulfur is explained by soft acid-soft base 21 interactions. [46]. 22 The role of the S-containing organo-silane is based on the Hard and Soft acid-base concept 23 [47]. Since the sulphur atom of organo-silane is a soft Lewis base, thus the interaction of the 24 sulfide group with the Hg(II), Pb(II) and Pd(II) cations as soft Lewis acid are stronger than 25
the other metal cations. In the absence of organosilane group, the selectivity and capacity of 1 the sorbent was decreased. 2 3

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Effect of solution pH 4
sections.text:
The pH of the aqueous solution plays an significant role in the metal ions removal, since pH 5 values affect not only the present metal ions forms in aqueous tested solution but also the 6 protonation degree of the functional groups in the adsorbent surface. The effect of pH on the 7 adsorption of Hg(II), Pd(II) and Pb(II) ions onto mesoporous adsorbent is illustrated in Fig. 8 11. It can be seen that with an increase of the aqueous solution pH from 1 to 8, adsorption 9 percentage of Hg(II), Pd(II), and Pb(II) ions were increased dramatically. The maximum 10 adsorption was detected at pH=4 for all metal ions. The sorbent can be protonated at the pH 11 value under the 2 while, the optimum pH for adsorption process was selected at pH=4. The 12 concentration of proton ions at lower pH, is much higher from the heavy metal ions. Thus, 13 there is a competition between metal ions and H+ ions on the surface of adsorbent, and 14 because of repulsive forces, the mentioned ions will be hindered from achieve the adsorbent 15 connection sites. With increasing pH, the competition between metal ions (positively 16 charged) and H+ (proton ions) at the sites of adsorbent surface are decreased, thus the 17 adsorption of heavy metals are increased. In addition, in higher value of pH (pH > 8), the 18 precipitation of metal cations in basic medium occurs because of the forming of metals 19 hydroxides which can be reduced the adsorption efficiency. As shown in Fig. 11, at pH = 4, 20 the maximum removal efficiencies of Hg(II), Pd(II) and Pb(II) ions were 98.8%, 96.4%, 21 95.7% respectively [29, 48, 49]. Therefore, in this study, pH=4 was selected as the optimum 22 pH for all following experiments. 23 24 Fig. 11 25

Effect of adsorbent amount 2 The effect of the amount of the nanoadsorbent on the removal of Hg(II), Pd(II) and 3 Pb(II) metal ions were carried out at room temperature and at pH=4 by varying amounts of 4 the adsorbent (i.e. 20-100 mg) in 10 mL of 50 mg L-1 solution of each metal ions (Fig. 12). 5 The results showed that the removal efficiency increased from 46.31% to 91.63% for Hg(II), 6 56.75% to 92.75% for Pd(II), and 69.57% to 96.63% for Pb(II) with the increase in dosage of 7 adsorbent from 20 to 50 mg. The removal trends of MSCMNPs-S4 is: Pb(II) > Hg(II) > 8 Pd(II). The Pb(II) ions have a better binding capacity with nanoadsorbent, because it has 9 higher molar mass and less amount of charge than Hg(II) ion. It can be seen from Fig. 12 that 10 the adsorption of metal ions was increased with the increase in adsorbent amounts. The 11 adsorption increasing is due to the more conection sites on the adsorbent surface to form 12 complexes with ions when the adsorbent amount increases. According to the results, 13 maximum removal percentage was obtained when nanomaterial adsorbent amount was above 14 50 mg. Therefore, 50 mg of adsorbent was used in all experiments. 15 16 Fig. 12 17 18 3.2.3. Effect of initial heavy metal ion concentrations 19 To study of the initial concentrations effects on the removal efficiency of the heavy 20 metal ions, a set of experiments were carried out at different metal ion concentrations of each 21 ion (10 - 100 mg L-1) under previously determined optimum conditions. It is observed that the 22 removal efficiency of toxic metal ions gradually decreases with the increase of the initial 23 concentration of metal ions. Due to the interaction between ions present in the solution and 24 on the adsorbent surface, at lower concentration after the mono ionic layer formation on the 25
surface of adsorbent, more layer formation is highly hindered at higher concentration. Also, 1 at low concentration of the analyte, the ratio of the ions initial mole for the available 2 adsorbent surface area is large and then, the part of the adsorption value becomes 3 independent from the initial ion concentration , but at the higher concentration, the available 4 adsorption sites decreas and therefore, the ions removal efficiency becomes lesser. Therefore, 5 the optimal concentration of the Hg(II), Pd(II) and Pb(II) metal ions were selected as 50 mg 6 L-1 due to maximum adsorption capacity. 7 8 3.2.4. Effect of contact time 9 For investigate the contact time effect on the removal efficiency of Hg(II), Pd(II), and 10 Pb(II) using the mesoporous MSCMNPs-S4 adsorbent, further tests were carried out at 11 constant temperature and pH=4 with the contacting time varying in the range of 5 - 45 min 12 and the results are shown in Fig. 13. It is clear that with increasing contact time, the adsorbed 13 amount of studied metal ions increases and reaches a constant value. This behavior may be 14 attributed to the high amount of active sites available on the mesoporous adsorbent surface 15 and to the high solute gradient of concentration. According to the results, the adsorption-16 desorption equilibrium between the ions and adsorbent was about 20 min, which this time is 17 shorter than results for other reported materials [50, 51]. sections.heading: 4. Conclusion 22
sections.text:
In the present study, magnetic mesoporous silica nanoparticles were successfully 23 synthesized using TEOS as the silica source and CTAB as surfactant template through a sol-24 gel process. Then, the resultant magnetite mesoporous silica nanospheres were modified with 25
bis(3-triethoxysilylpropyl)tetrasulfide (MSCMNPs-S4) and were used as a convenient and 1 effective adsorbent for the removal of Hg(II), Pd(II) and Pb(II) ions from aqueous samples by 2 batch technique. After that, the HCl and HNO3 solutions as eluent were applied for 3 desorption of metal ions from adsorbent surface. The prepared adsorbent was characterized 4 by FT-IR, SEM, TEM, XRD, VSM, TGA, BET, EDX, DLS, and UV-Vis. The effect of 5 different parameters like initial concentration, solution pH, type, and quantity of contact time 6 and eluent on the adsorption process was systematically explored. Batch adsorption tests 7 revealed that the optimal parameters condition for Hg(II), Pd(II) and Pb(II) ions removal by 8 mesoporous adsorbents were pH=4 and 20 min contact time. The Langmuir isotherm was 9 obtained as successfully modeling of the adsorption isotherm, which representing a 10 monolayer chemical adsorption of metal ions onto mesoporous adsorbent. The maximum 11 adsorption capacities of Hg(II), Pd(II) and Pb(II) ions were found to be 303.03, 256.41 and 12 270.27 mg g-1, respectively. The observed differences in the maximum capacities of the 13 studied heavy metal ions were found to be perhaps due to their distinct affinity to interaction 14 with sulfide groups (soft base) of the MSCMNPs-S4 surface. Also, the methanolic solution of 15 hydrochloric acid (1 M) was selected as optimal eluent for elution of metal ions. This 16 adsorbent exhibits the advantages of high ions adsorption, desorption efficiency and 17 convenience of separation in compare with other conventional materials. The results indicate 18 that these products are potentially attractive materials for the removal of toxic metal ions 19 from aqueous matrices. 20 21 Acknowledgments 22 The authors wish to thank University of Tehran for financial support.
